segments.text: Alright everyone, let's debrief this morning's incident. First - how's Carlos doing?
He's okay. Minor laceration on his hand, got five stitches at the clinic. Doctor cleared him to return to light duty tomorrow.
Good. That could've been much worse. Tony, walk me through what happened.
Carlos was cutting rebar with the angle grinder. Blade caught and kicked back, hit his hand. He was wearing gloves but not the cut-resistant ones.
Why wasn't he wearing cut-resistant gloves? That's standard PPE for grinding operations.
He said they were uncomfortable and he'd been using regular gloves all week. No one caught it until after the incident.
That's a supervision failure. Elena, you're the safety officer - how did this slip through?
I did my walkthrough at 7 AM, before he started that task. By the time I came back around, it had already happened.
So we have a gap. Toolbox talks happen in the morning, but tasks change throughout the day.
Right. Carlos switched from form work to rebar cutting around 10 AM. Different hazards, different PPE requirements.
Okay here's what we're changing. Effective immediately: any time a worker changes tasks, they do a quick safety check with their supervisor. Takes two minutes.
I like that. We can create a simple checklist - task, hazards, required PPE. Sign off and go.
Perfect. Elena, draft that today. I want it implemented tomorrow morning. Also, we need to address the comfort issue with the cut-resistant gloves.
I'll order samples from three different manufacturers. Let the crew test them and pick the ones they'll actually wear.
Good thinking. If the PPE is uncomfortable, people won't use it. We need to find gear that protects AND doesn't make their job harder.
Should we discipline Carlos for not wearing proper PPE?
This is a teaching moment, not a punishment moment. Carlos got hurt - that's consequence enough. We fix the system so it doesn't happen again.
